reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s move in §2.1 from “many moral views see the present as deeply flawed” to “a single flaw can wipe out much of the value of the future,” arguing this leans on disagreement without a defended intertheoretic aggregation. This is moderately central: it supports the ‘eutopia is fragile’ motivation, but the essay’s main case also relies on independent considerations (multiplicative fragility model, resource-scaling/boundedness analysis), so falsifying the §2.1 rhetorical support wouldn’t collapse the whole position. The critique has some bite against over-reading the historical-survey-as-probabilistic-evidence, but it overstates by implying the essay straightforwardly treats moral uncertainty as expected value loss without method—later sections explicitly discuss intertheoretic comparisons and uncertainty. Overall: mostly correct, clearly expressed, focused, with little fluff, but it only modestly weakens a supporting strand rather than the core argument.
title: Moral disagreement does not imply large expected value loss
